update.description:
This is a work in progress branch for implementing Frame Semantics in sdf 1.7 based on the following proposal:

* http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs

This is not yet ready for review. It requires [ign-math pull request 333](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/333/graphalgorithms-add-functions-for-finding/diff).
update.title: WIP: Frame semantics for sdf 1.7

We still need to add the ResolvePose functions for a few more DOM objects:

* model scope: Light, Sensor
* world scope: everything

We still need to add the ResolvePose functions for a few more DOM objects:

  • model scope: Light, Sensor
  • world scope: everything

content.raw: Per f2f, we should deprecate the accessors to raw data that now have semantics, e.g. `::Pose()`, `::Xyz()`, etc., and replace them with `::RawPose()` or something like that. \(Perhaps for the setters too?\)
content.html: Per f2f, we should deprecate the accessors to raw data that now have semantics, e.g. ::Pose(), ::Xyz(), etc., and replace them with ::RawPose() or something like that. (Perhaps for the setters too?)

content.raw: I'll give it a shot
content.html: I'll give it a shot

content.raw: Is it hard to teach this to transform `//joint/use_parent_model_frame==1` to `//joint/axis/xyz[@expressed_in=”__model__”]`?
content.html: Is it hard to teach this to transform //joint/use_parent_model_frame==1 to //joint/axis/xyz[@expressed_in=”__model__”]?

content.raw:
Fixed!

However, the parser does not fail fast when it encounters a reserved `//frame[@name]`, like `{"world", "model", "world"}`:

[https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/8f4f7ab1ee1bfe77db5c8dcaf152e3b9fd7ffec7](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/8f4f7ab1ee1bfe77db5c8dcaf152e3b9fd7ffec7)

Would it be possible to add that behavior in?

EDIT: Per spec: [http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose\_frame\_semantics\_proposal&cat=pose\_semantics\_docs&#element-naming-rule-reserved-names](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#element-naming-rule-reserved-names)
content.html:
Fixed!

However, the parser does not fail fast when it encounters a reserved //frame[@name], like {"world", "model", "world"}:

https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/8f4f7ab1ee1bfe77db5c8dcaf152e3b9fd7ffec7

Would it be possible to add that behavior in?

EDIT: Per spec: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&cat=pose_semantics_docs&#element-naming-rule-reserved-names

content.raw: Ah, d’oh! I was explicitly resolving poses using ““. Lemme fix that!
content.html: Ah, d’oh! I was explicitly resolving poses using ““. Lemme fix that!

content.raw: probably caused by 8019ec5, which uses `__model__` and `__world__` as vertex names instead of `""`
content.html: probably caused by 8019ec5, which uses __model__ and __world__ as vertex names instead of ""

content.raw:
Sweet! Trying it out now; it seems to have broken some of my tests \(saying that `Unique vertex with name [] not found in graph.`\), so I'll see what I need to update:

[https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/cfc625e1d5f9cfc2d62c7c4a252c998f5405226f](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/cfc625e1d5f9cfc2d62c7c4a252c998f5405226f)
content.html:
Sweet! Trying it out now; it seems to have broken some of my tests (saying that Unique vertex with name [] not found in graph.), so I'll see what I need to update:

https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/pull/12061/commits/cfc625e1d5f9cfc2d62c7c4a252c998f5405226f

content.raw: I've implemented `JointAxis::ResolveXyz` and added tests
content.html: I've implemented JointAxis::ResolveXyz and added tests

content.raw:
I'm experimenting with an xslt for converting from urdf to sdf 1.7

try it from the root of the repository with the following:

~~~
xsltproc \
  sdf/1.7/urdf_to_sdf17.xslt \
  test/performance/parser_urdf_atlas.urdf \
  > atlas.urdf
~~~
content.html:
I'm experimenting with an xslt for converting from urdf to sdf 1.7

try it from the root of the repository with the following:

xsltproc \
  sdf/1.7/urdf_to_sdf17.xslt \
  test/performance/parser_urdf_atlas.urdf \
  > atlas.urdf

content.raw:
I’ve submitted the following addendum to the proposal.

Posed a question here: [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf\_tutorials/pull-requests/35/update-pose-frame-proposal-to-support-xyz/diff#Lpose\_frame\_semantics/proposal.mdT740](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/35/update-pose-frame-proposal-to-support-xyz/diff#Lpose_frame_semantics/proposal.mdT740) - can you look at it there?
content.html:
I’ve submitted the following addendum to the proposal.

Posed a question here: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/35/update-pose-frame-proposal-to-support-xyz/diff#Lpose_frame_semantics/proposal.mdT740 - can you look at it there?

content.raw: Submitted. See below.
content.html: Submitted. See below.

content.raw: yeah, for referring to the model frame from a joint, there would currently need to be a `//frame`
content.html: yeah, for referring to the model frame from a joint, there would currently need to be a //frame

content.raw:
For specifying `//axis/xyz[@expressed_in]`, I’m now more concerned about the ambiguity between `@relative_to`s different states: does empty mean default? If so, how does one refer to the model? We force users to explicitly add the frame?

We’ve mentioned not providing the user to specify `__model__` implicitly… but maybe we do that? Otherwise, for transitioning, not only does the value have to change, but some arbitrary frame has to be added to accommodate referring to it…
content.html:
For specifying //axis/xyz[@expressed_in], I’m now more concerned about the ambiguity between @relative_tos different states: does empty mean default? If so, how does one refer to the model? We force users to explicitly add the frame?

We’ve mentioned not providing the user to specify __model__ implicitly… but maybe we do that? Otherwise, for transitioning, not only does the value have to change, but some arbitrary frame has to be added to accommodate referring to it…

content.raw: I'm working on the slides right now; if you are able to implement it in a branch, I'll review it and merge it in
content.html: I'm working on the slides right now; if you are able to implement it in a branch, I'll review it and merge it in

content.raw:
To check, do you think it’d be feasible to add this in here? :D

\(Or do you want me to take a quick whack at it, and do the necessary changes to the proposal writeup too?\)
content.html:
To check, do you think it’d be feasible to add this in here? :D

(Or do you want me to take a quick whack at it, and do the necessary changes to the proposal writeup too?)
